video.title: Data Structures Easy to Advanced Course - Full Tutorial from a Google Engineer
video.description:
Learn and master the most common data structures in this full course from Google engineer William Fiset. This course teaches data structures to beginners using high quality animations to represent the data structures visually.

You will learn how to code various data structures together with simple to follow step-by-step instructions. Every data structure presented will be accompanied by some working source code (in Java) to solidify your understanding.

💻 Code: https://github.com/williamfiset/data-structures

🎥 Course created by William Fiset. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCD8yeTczadqdARzQUp29PJw

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️

topLevelComment.author: Justyna K.
topLevelComment.text:
Not sure if anyone already commented on this. In the Queues section - it's worth mentioning that there are two types of queues - First In First Out (FIFO) and First In Last Out (FILO). In the video, the visualisation of the queue shows FIFO queue, but visualisation of implementation through LinkedList shows FILO queue instead, which may be confusing for the viewers.

edit:
FIFO are queues and FILO are stacks, so a FILO stack was presented as a queue.

replies.author: Andrew Moore
replies.text:
@Sanket Rao Its actually both, but it doesn't cover every algo, it covers the most commonly used DS and then the algos that are used on those DS. I'm on the Binary Search Tree section and we're looking at code written for that, Binary Trees can be implemented in many different ways, so this lecture is a little of algo but mostly DS.

If you're comfortable with DS already, meaning you already understand why how and where to use things like, Stacks, Queues, Priority Queues, Hash Tables, Arrays etc. Then I'd suggest watching a series that is specific only to algos.

I can recommend this one, which I plan on watching next. And then below that you can see the videos I plan on watching after, in order. I find that you don't really know something if you haven't been exposed to it a few times by a couple instructors. Hope this helps.

Algorithms and Data Structures Tutorial - Full Course for Beginners

Dynamic Programming - Learn to Solve Algorithmic Problems & Coding Challenges

Graph Algorithms for Technical Interviews - Full Course

Machine Learning Algorithms | Machine Learning Tutorial | Data Science Algorithms | Simplilearn

replies.author: Andrew Moore
replies.text: He actually explains it pretty well, Big-O takes the worst part of any equation and uses that to determine the time(speed) an algorithm might run in the worst case scenario. So when he shows a function like f(n) = n^2 * n^3 + 1 you know that the only part you're really worried about is the N^3 because that is going to cause the most significant slowdowns in your algorithm. And yes there are other videos, just search for Big-O tutorials.

topLevelComment.author: Arnon Marcus
topLevelComment.text:
3:29:00 You haven't really defined what exactly "successor" means - and it only really be defined in-terms of the in-order traversal - which you haven't covered by that point (it only comes later as the next topic). I got confused because I thought it means "what should come after the node being removed" (with "after" being w.r.t the in-order traversal order) - which is completely wrong, because if it were that, then the successor would always-always be in the right sub-tree, yet as you then point out, it can actually be in either/both. The problem is that this is NOT exactly the definition of what "successor" means - it's NOT the one that comes after the node being removed - but rather, the one that comes after "the 'predecessor' of the node being removed"(!) So now you have to define "predecessor", again, in terms of in-order traversal. This is a pretty easy to get confused about, so it shouldn't be glossed-over. I think a better way to describe it, is instead of in terms of "successor"/"predecessor", you simply ask: 
"Of all the nodes in both sub-trees of the node being removed, which would be valid to be placed instead of it?"
This would more-closely follow the notion of the invariant being maintain, and also completely side-step the notions of "predecessor"/"successor" and traversal orders and the need to define those.

topLevelComment.author: Arnon Marcus
topLevelComment.text:
1:39:09 : Is this even a tree? The node in the middle there with 6 in it has 2 parents (3 and 6)
In the example after, you said if the structure is not a tree, then it's not a heap, so shouldn't it also apply to this one?
Also, the second one, you phrased it as "not being a tree" because it has "a cycle" but that's not the property that invalidates a structure from being a tree, it's sufficient that a node has more than one parent, it may-or-my-not be cyclical. Also, you can't really use the term "cycle" on a non-directed graph - if it's directed, the edges should have arrows. A DAG can have the structure that the non-tree example here shows, while still being a DAG (non-cyclical)

topLevelComment.author: Francis Pang
topLevelComment.text:
May I know is there a difference in time complexity if we implemented the path compression on the find method or the merge method? 
From what I understand, it is more computational expensive to place the path compression on the merge method, because we do not need to know the root at the time of merging. However, if we look at Krushal's algorithm, the worst that is that we will revisit each node post-merging, and there won't be any time saving overall.

topLevelComment.text:
I have to make a schedule viewer but I don't know what data structure I should use...
The csv files are loaded and the program asks users to choose one from options. And the program shows schedules based on the user selection(like list by specific lecturer, list by modules etc.)
This is how my program should be worked.
In this case,what data structure should I use?
I'd really appreciated if you could help me out!

replies.author: Brian walnut
replies.text: Well assuming you have to use a data structure just use a list. For each row in your csv file add an object with the csv headers as keys to the list. Once everything is in a list just sort the list by the object keys.

replies.author: Stan None
replies.text:
array = [1,4,5,2,7,8,9,22];
n = array.length; // number (the count: 8) of elements in the array
Question: How many look ups in to the array you need to do to find the number "22"?
Answer:  8 times, if looking in to each index from 0 to 7.

Conclusion: in the worst possible cases, 1. the number you are looking for is at the end or 2. not there at all, you will need to look in to the array at every index. For array with 6 elements, you need to look 6 times and so on. That means O(n). n is the number of elements in the array.

This is basically it. How many operation, in the worst possible case, do you need to do to complete.

topLevelComment.author: Madhukiran Attivilli
topLevelComment.text:
https://youtu.be/RBSGKlAvoiM?t=22319
Fenwick tree
LSB(i) = i & -i
-i = 2s complement of i
2s complement of i = 1s complement of i + 1

example : LSB(10)
10 = 0b00001010
1s complement of 10 = 0b11110101
1s complement of 10 + 1 = 0b11110110
So -10 & 10 = 0b 0000 1010 &0b 1111 0110
= 0b 0000 0010
= 2^1 
= 2
- Madhukiran

topLevelComment.author: Madhukiran Attivilli
topLevelComment.text:
https://youtu.be/RBSGKlAvoiM?t=16191
Hashtable
Separate Chaining source code
not sure if ur normalizeIndex() defn is correct.
You're ignoring the sign bit and taking the rest of the value.
But -ve values are stored in 2s complement notation.
For example a 32bit number 1 + 30 0s + 1 is 1s complement of that (0 + 30 1s + 0) + 1 = 0 + 31 1s (coz 2s complement is 1s complement + 1). 31 1s is 2^31 -1. Hence 1 + 30 0s + 1 is -(2^31 -1). If we wanna take the absolute value, normalizeIndex should return 2^31 - 1, which would be 0 + 31 1s.
But, ur normalizeIndex() method would return 0 + 30 0s + 1 = 1.
I guess the normalizeIndex(keyHash) method should return the 2s complement of input parameter whenever the sign bit is 1. OR, best would be to just call abs(keyHash) or return -1 * keyHash whenever keyHash < 0.
PLEASE COMMENT.
- Madhukiran

topLevelComment.author: Madhukiran Attivilli
topLevelComment.text:
https://youtu.be/RBSGKlAvoiM?t=14177
BST
remove() op
I wud recommend 2 improvements to ur code :
(1) when contains() has already located the node, why remove() has to traverse again from root! Instead, we can directly start the "remove" work from the searched node
(2) when the searched node has both left and right subtrees -- diveLeft() already gave the smallest in right subtree. We can directly remove it (using "node has only left or right subtree logic). No need to once again traverse from <searched node>.right till the <smallest nodes in right sub tree>
- Madhukiran

topLevelComment.author: Madhukiran Attivilli
topLevelComment.text:
https://youtu.be/RBSGKlAvoiM?t=14177
BST
height(node)
the stack of recursive calls can be TREMENDOUSLY reduced with 1 additional stmt
if(node == null) return 0;
if(node.left == null && node.right == null) return 1;  <--- THIS LINE
return max(height(node.left), height(node.right)) + 1;
- Madhukiran

topLevelComment.author: Madhukiran Attivilli
topLevelComment.text:
https://youtu.be/RBSGKlAvoiM?t=8219
Priority Queue using Binary Heap. BH using Array & Hashtable :
create heap via heapify approach :
The pdf has maths formula to arrive at O(n) time complexity for heapify, and is definitely impossible to understand unless one is expert in integration and other complex maths concepts.

A simple way :
for tree height = 3, calculate number of nodes at each level, and number of levels to sink down in worst case (sink till leaf node level), get their product, and add the products for all levels. Similarly do for height = 4 5 6 etc. And u will notice that total cost would be = n - (h+1) where n is number of nodes in the tree, and h is the tree height. So, Big-O would be O(n) as n >> h (h wud be a tiny number than n)

- Madhukiran

replies.author: NicosoftNT
replies.text:
​@Gamer That's incorrect, 1 does not work on that equation... 1^2 + 1/2=n^2;
1 + 0.5 = 1; *1.5 = 1* which is incorrect.
0 Doesn't work either because 0/2 is infinite, and infinite does not equal to 0.
By the way, I am suspicious about your third  step, seems a little off. My solution to that is the following: 

n^2 + n = 2 * n^2;
n = 2*n^2 - n^2;
*n = n^2;*

As you can see, this is totally wrong, and
after doing some calculations, this is true for all n in all of the steps except from the first one. And this is odd because when you analyze the first one you realize that it's also wrong!

n^2/2 + x/2 = n^2 (lets give n the number 2)

2^2/2 + 2/2 = 2^2;
2 + 1 = 4;  *3=4* 😂😂😂😂😂😂😂

However, the number 1 does work in this case:

0.5 + 0.5 = 1

replies.author: Gamer
replies.text: Where does he mention that? Timestamp?

replies.author: Gamer
replies.text:
n^2/2+n/2 = n^2
n^2 + n = 2 • n^2
n + n/n = 2/n • n = 2
n + 1 = 2
n = 1

1²/2 + 1/2 = 1² = 1

1 is the only number with which n²+n/2 = n².

topLevelComment.text:
BIG-O: notação que define a a complexidade do algoritmo no seu pior cenário. Ela ajuda a quantificar a performance do algoritmo (considera o tempo de execução do código e o espaço alocado).

BIG-O
N = o tamanho do espaço dos dados de entrada ordenado do menor para o maior
Constant time  = O(1)
Logarithmic time =O(log(n))
Linear Time = 0(N)
Linearithmic time = O(nlog(n))
Quadric time = O(n2)
Cubic time o(n³)
Exponencial time o(b elevado a n), B>1
Factorial time o(n!)

topLevelComment.author: てじゃs
topLevelComment.text:
If you are wondering how does Big O of binary search algo turns out to be log(n). Here is what I found - 


At Iteration 1,
Length of array = n
At Iteration 2,
Length of array = n⁄2
At Iteration 3,
Length of array = (n⁄2)⁄2 = n⁄22
Therefore, after Iteration k,
Length of array = n⁄2k
Also, we know that after
After k divisions, the length of array becomes 1
Therefore
Length of array = n⁄2k = 1
=> n = 2k
Applying log function on both sides:
=> log2 (n) = log2 (2k)
=> log2 (n) = k log2 (2)
As (loga (a) = 1)
Therefore,
=> k = log2 (n)

How we're going to make the food would be a DS? feel free to come up with your own examples below.

replies.author: Ricardo M. Ianelli
replies.text:
Another good example is thinking about inheritance in OOP.

A mammal has some properties that defines them, they:
- Have 3 middle ear bones
- Have mammary glands so they can produce milk

This is what defines them, the Abstract type.
But mammals can be of a variety of types with different configurations, i mean, a bat is really different than a human, right?
Because they both are implementations, they both are like data structures, but they both respect the definition of mammals, having mammary glands and 3 middle ear bones, so they respect the abstract type.

replies.author: Ricardo M. Ianelli
replies.text:
The ADT is the contract, the DS is the implementation.
In your case, you can eat chicken, but fried? Baked? 
Do the implementation change the fact that you're eating chicken?

topLevelComment.author: BLAX
topLevelComment.text:
1:38:34 This is actually not a valid heap. Heaps are almost complete data structures. That means that heap cant have skips in adding new elements. This means adding elements is always by adding element to the left then to the right of the parent, and you should first add nodes to parent then skip to another node. And rule is that every parent has 0,1 or 2 child, but in the example root has 3 children. That is definitely not a heap.

EDIT: realized half of examples are not heaps. Just google what is heap and rules to make heap and you will see that this examples that he said are heaps, are not actually.

topLevelComment.author: Shamy
topLevelComment.text:
It's better to implement Stack using ArrayDeque than using LinkedList:
1. ArrayDeque is faster. (Look at ArrayDeque documentation)
2. LinkedList consumes more memory than ArrayDeque because LinkedList is a doubly-linked list.

replies.author: Andreea Diana Chiriac
replies.text: It depends on the language. Most languages have their own `stack` library/module, which is by far the best way to approach it. Linked List consume more memory, but it's really hard to think about a situation where the memory limit may be reached... but there is no way to say that linked lists are slower than a normal array. Deque is a different data structure.

replies.author: Mansimar anand
replies.text:
lists and queues for parsing.


hash tables, tries, and other in-memory "speed" structures for metadata (i.e, table definitions and such things).


Some more specific to db engines are Pages and Rows, which are dynamic in their definitions and can't be completely stated as static structures in any programming language.  In this sense, they're more like networking packets than more traditional data structures.  Pages and Rows will be used in index structures and base table storage.


One aside: the vast majority of data structures in a database don't actually have anything to do with storage.  They're for parsing, query optimization, query execution, concurrency, query scheduling, managing application connections, etc.

replies.author: Brent Jackson
replies.text:
O(1) means how long the algorithm takes does not depend on the number of elements in the structure. 

What's the first node in a linked list? This function is O(1) because it doesn't matter if there's 1 node in the list or 1,000,000 getting the first node will take the same amount of time.

How many times is the number 7 in my linked list? This will take O(n) because you have to look at each node. If checking 1 node takes 1 second, 10 nodes will take 10 seconds and 1,000 nodes will take 1,000 seconds. The time the algorithm takes is proportional to how many nodes there are in the structure.
